--- Derek James <blue5432@...> wrote:
<snip>
> Check out the message archives for this forum.  See
> Darren Izzard's first message (#8), and the ensuing
> "Shape Recognition" thread.  Similar idea.
<snip>

I read through that thread.  Now there are three ways
of doing this! :)

Originally, I had only considered looking at the whole
table, meaning that the ANN has inputs for the state
of every position.

A second way of doing it, based on my
misinterpretation of what you said, is to give to the
ANN all of the CHANGES to the table.  Since the
starting information is "all cards face down", the
theoreticall, if you know all the changes, that's
equivalent to knowing the exact state of the table.

Now I see what you have been talking about, which is
to let the ANN have a small scanning window and let it
spend several computational steps looking over the
table.  At least, that's what Darren's method is when
applied to this game.

All of those may be worth trying.

There is another large architectural decision here,
which I might get some opinions on.  I have been
planning to start with a sharp threshold function for
the activation function, rather than a sigmoidal
function.  My reasoning is that, since the inputs and
final outputs are binary, why not use binary neurons? 
The weight & thresholds will be the only floating
point numbers in the ANN.  Everything else will be 0's
and 1's, and integers to boot.  I think this will
allow me to code a faster calculating ANN, which in
turn speeds up the number of generations per hour.
I'm planning on using a fully connected binary ANN,
meaning that every neural output is also an input to
every neuron, through a weight of course.  So for N
neurons we have an NxN matrix of weights.  (I'm not
using NEAT, as I have mentioned previously, but I hope
someone else tries NEAT on this problem.)
There is another matrix of weights for the external
inputs.
